issues.description: The problem statement explicitly requires a no-argument Farm constructor that initializes the internal ArrayList ("Initialize the ArrayList in a constructor with no arguments"). The solution implementation only provides a Farm(int initialCapacity) constructor and lacks the required no-argument constructor. This mismatch means code (and tests or the provided Main) that expects new Farm() will fail (animals will be null or the constructor won't exist), preventing students from following the specified API and causing runtime or compile-time errors.
issues.suggested_fix: Add a public no-argument constructor to Farm that initializes the animals list (e.g. public Farm() { this.animals = new ArrayList<>(); }). You may keep the existing Farm(int initialCapacity) constructor as an overload, but the no-arg constructor must exist to match the problem specification and the usage in Main/templates.
